stream_context.summary: Kaze prototyped and debugged a Mario-Paint-style minigame inside Return to Yoshi’s Island in which the player physically paints a Mario sprite, then has their work graded by a newly-modeled Mario Paint ‘Save Robot’. Most of the stream revolved around coding the paint system’s fill, score, reset logic, and building the robot NPC model.

development_findings.summary: Created a dynamic ‘virtual texture’ that lets players draw directly on Mario’s face by writing to texture memory at runtime.
development_findings.quote: You can draw anything you want really—you can even color in Mario.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a non-recursive flood-fill algorithm that pushes candidate pixels onto a manually allocated stack in ROM because normal recursion would overflow the N64 stack.
development_findings.quote: The stack is not big enough for that, so I can't do that. I just allocated memory in temporary ROM space and use it as a stack for pixels to be checked.

development_findings.summary: Fixed a bug where clearing the canvas did not reset the score, which allowed infinite points. Refactored the score logic into its own function and separate storage.
development_findings.quote: This gets rid of the color on Mario so you can view it without drawing … but it doesn’t reset your score, so you can get infinite score. That needs to reset your score.

development_findings.summary: Set an initial star-award threshold: if the internal ‘error’ value drops below one million the player receives the star. Tested how inaccurate a drawing can be before failing.
development_findings.quote: You can mess up a fair bit before it doesn't work anymore … honestly, if you draw Mario like this you don't really deserve the star.

development_findings.summary: Chose the Mario Paint ‘Save/Load Robot’ (internally nick-named Corespond) as the grading NPC after rejecting Undo Dog to avoid implying there is an undo feature.
development_findings.quote: Undo Dog will make people think they can undo, and I will absolutely not add undo to this.

development_findings.summary: Modeled the robot as a relatively high-poly (≈300 triangles) 3D object because the sub-area is small and still runs at a stable 60 FPS.
development_findings.quote: It's less than Mario's model, so it's not that bad. This area is gonna run really well anyway.

development_findings.summary: Discovered roughly 1 MB of ‘hidden’ 9-bit memory on N64 that can be accessed via CPU tricks; may explore it for extra storage or a future tech-explanation video.
development_findings.quote: Secretly all the bytes on the N64 are nine bits … you can read and write the ninth bit with a few tricks.

development_findings.summary: Parallel RDP currently crashes with RTYI; Kaze discussed failed debugging attempts with developer Falco and is using Project64 as the primary test emulator.
development_findings.quote: I tried to fix the RTYI crash, but we literally couldn't figure it out. It just doesn't work in Parallel.

development_findings.summary: Long-term plan to asset-swap RTYI (replace all Mario IP) and release it as an original indie game once the hack is finished.
development_findings.quote: If I swap Mario and all the other [assets] that could be my first indie game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is married; he and his wife Zeina are replaying Twilight Princess, which reminds him he prefers open-world exploration over dungeon-centric design.
context_findings.quote: Me and Zeina, we're currently playing through Twilight Princess … I realized what I like in Zelda games is the open world, not the dungeons.

context_findings.summary: Personal design philosophy: values challenge and simplicity over convenience; refuses to implement an undo feature in the paint minigame.
context_findings.quote: You mess up, you lose your points. It's still a game, guys. This is not an image editor.

context_findings.summary: Dislikes 2D platformers and most boss fights, shaping how he designs levels and mechanics.
context_findings.quote: I don't like 2D platformers, like at all … I don't like boss fights in video games. They're very boring.

context_findings.summary: Plans to livestream Roblox on Sunday because Roblox corporate is paying him; shows willingness to take sponsored streams for revenue.
context_findings.quote: They're paying me money to stream Roblox—I'd be stupid not to take that.

context_findings.summary: Avoids politically themed hacks now; feels the current climate would react negatively compared to 2016’s Trump 64.
context_findings.quote: If I do the same thing in 2024 with a Trump 64 ROM hack, people will murder me.

context_findings.summary: Aware of legal risk in asset-swap indie idea; intends to consult a lawyer.
context_findings.quote: Either way, it's definitely something I would have to talk to a lawyer about.

zeina.summary: Plays Zelda titles with Kaze and influences his reflection on exploration-heavy versus dungeon-heavy design.
zeina.quote: Me and Zeina, we're currently playing through Twilight Princess.

key_stories.title: Fixing the infinite-score exploit
key_stories.summary: Clearing the paint canvas did not reset the internal score counter, allowing players to farm infinite points. Kaze traced the issue to shared state and refactored the scoring code.
key_stories.challenge: Players could wipe the canvas and keep their accumulated points.
key_stories.process: Identified the shared variable, moved scoring data into its own structure, and turned the wipe logic into a separate function.
key_stories.outcome: Score now resets correctly; exploit removed.
key_stories.key_quote: This doesn't reset your score, so you can get infinite score. That needs to reset your score.

key_stories.title: Choosing an evaluator NPC
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed an in-game character to grade the player’s painting. Undo Dog was first suggestion, but he worried it would imply an undo function.
key_stories.challenge: Find a recognizable Mario Paint reference that won’t confuse players.
key_stories.process: Discussed options with chat; settled on the ‘Save Robot’. Began modeling a 3D version and confirmed performance budget.
key_stories.outcome: Robot NPC chosen and partially modeled; logic hooks into ‘ask Mario’ dialogue system.
key_stories.key_quote: Undo Dog will make people think that they can undo, and I will absolutely not add undo to this.

key_stories.title: Exploring hidden 1 MB N64 memory
key_stories.summary: Kaze explained a little-known 9-bit memory quirk on the N64 that could free roughly 1 MB of extra space.
key_stories.challenge: Memory is slow and awkward to access, normally reserved for pixel coverage data.
key_stories.process: Outlined CPU tricks to read/write odd bits and mused about rendering sub-pixel triangles as a write method.
key_stories.outcome: No implementation yet; possible future tech video and experimental storage for RTYI.
key_stories.key_quote: I know it sounds crazy, but it's there—an entire megabyte of memory no one really uses.
